During the second presidential debate on October 10th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that Hillary Clinton was involved in a decision as Secretary of State that was laughed at all over the world. He was referring to President Obama's "red line" in Syria, where he stated that the use of chemical weapons by Bashar al-Assad would change his calculus on armed intervention. Clinton interrupted Trump, denying her involvement, but Trump argued that she was in contact with the White House and that Obama probably still listened to her. Fact-checking reveals that while Clinton was Secretary of State when Obama drew the red line in August 2012, she had been replaced by John Kerry by the time it was confirmed that Assad had crossed the red line in August 2013. However, Clinton was involved in the discussions about how to respond and publicly endorsed the White House's position. Therefore, Trump's claim has an element of truth but leaves out critical information, leading to a mostly false rating.
Donald Trump says ICE endorsed him

During the second presidential debate on October 10th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that there has been an increase in murder within our cities, the biggest in 45 years. This claim is largely accurate, as the number of murders and nonnegligent homicides rose nationally between 2014 and 2015 by 10.8 percent, which is the biggest yeartoyear jump in murders since 1970-71. However, it is important to note that crime rates were heading downward for a quarter-century before this recent increase, and the recent uptick is not significant enough to erase those gains. Criminologists agree that while the increase in murder rates is worth noting, it needs to be understood within a broader context. Therefore, Trump's statement is mostly true but requires clarification and additional information.

During the second presidential debate on October 9th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that Hillary Clinton laughed at a 12-year-old girl who was raped after she helped the accused man. Trump referred to an audio tape where Clinton can be heard laughing, but fact-checkers found that she was actually laughing at the oddities of the case involving the prosecution and the judge, not at the victim. Therefore, Trump's claim was rated as false.

During the second presidential debate on October 10th, 2016, Hillary Clinton criticized Donald Trump for his proposal to ban Muslims from entering the United States. Clinton argued that Trump's comments were unwise and dangerous, and that they were being used as propaganda by terrorist groups to recruit fighters. She cited examples of videos from al-Shabaab and ISIS that featured Trump's statements about Muslims and called for American Muslims to join the terrorist cause. Clinton's claim was rated as true, although it is difficult to determine the exact impact of Trump's words on recruitment.

During the second presidential debate on October 10th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that a tweet he sent out about former Miss Universe Alicia Machado was not telling people to "check out a sex tape," but rather to just take a look at her background. However, the tweet he sent at 5:30 a.m. on September 30th did literally say "check out sex tape." Fact-checkers rated his statement as "pants on fire" because he did direct his followers to check out a sex tape.
Trump: Clinton won't use the term 'radical Islamic terrorists'

During the presidential debate on October 9th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that Hillary Clinton wants to move the United States to a single-payer system for healthcare, similar to Canada. He argued that the Canadian healthcare system is slow and catastrophic, and that many Canadians come to the United States for major operations. However, fact-checkers have found that Clinton does not actually support a single-payer system. While she does support a public option for Obamacare, which is a single-payer-like option, she has not called for a complete transition to a single-payer system. Therefore, Trump's claim is false.

During the second presidential debate on October 9th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that Hillary Clinton deleted 33,000 emails after receiving a subpoena. The FBI investigation found that Clinton's staff received a subpoena for Benghazi-related emails on March 4th, 2015, and an employee managing her server deleted the emails three weeks later. However, the FBI also found no evidence that the emails were intentionally deleted to avoid the subpoena. Clinton's team had requested the deletion of the emails months before the subpoena was issued, and they argued that all relevant emails had already been turned over to the State Department. Therefore, Trump's claim is rated as half true by Politifact.

During the second presidential debate in St. Louis, Hillary Clinton claimed that the United States currently has the highest health insurance coverage in its history, with 90% of Americans covered. This claim was supported by data from the U.S. Census Bureau, which reported that 90.9% of Americans had some form of health coverage in 2015, the highest percentage recorded. The uninsured rate had also declined from 16.3% in 2010 to 9.1% in 2015. Therefore, Clinton's statement was rated as true.

During a campaign stop in Florida, Donald Trump claimed that Hillary Clinton promised to create 200,000 jobs for upstate New York during her 2000 Senate campaign, but not only did she fail to deliver on that promise, but the region also lost many jobs. The Washington Post analyzed Clinton's pledge and concluded that while her efforts fell flat, the area did not actually lose jobs. However, when looking at just private-sector jobs and using different definitions of upstate New York, it is true that Clinton did not meet her jobs target and the region did lose jobs. Overall, Trump's claim is mostly true.

During the vice presidential debate on October 10th, 2016, Tim Kaine claimed that Donald Trump said "Mexicans are rapists and criminals." Mike Pence responded by saying, "Senator, you've whipped out that Mexican thing again." Kaine continued to press the issue, and Pence defended Trump by saying that he also said "many of them [Mexicans] are good people." While Pence is correct that Kaine left out that part of the quote, it is important to note that Trump actually said "some" rather than "many" and added "I assume" which undermines the sentiment. The claim is partially accurate but lacks important context, so it is rated as half true.

During the vice presidential debate on October 5th, 2016, Democrat Tim Kaine claimed to Republican Mike Pence that Philando Castile, a Minnesota man who was shot and killed by a police officer during a traffic stop, had been stopped by police 40 or 50 times before the fatal incident. Kaine argued that this demonstrated a pattern of bias in law enforcement. Multiple independent press reports, including one commissioned by the state legislature, confirmed that Castile had been stopped by police at least 46 times, supporting Kaine's claim.

CLAIM: During the October 19th, 2016 presidential debate, Hillary Clinton claimed that Donald Trump has said that more countries should have nuclear weapons.

EXPLANATION: Clinton's claim is based on various statements made by Trump in interviews and debates. Trump has suggested that countries like Japan and South Korea might be better off if they had nuclear weapons to defend themselves against threats like North Korea. However, he has also stated that he opposes nuclear proliferation in general. Therefore, Clinton's claim is rated as mostly false.

During the October 4th vice presidential debate, Republican Mike Pence claimed that if Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine are elected, the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) will be expanded into a single-payer program. However, this claim is mostly false. While Clinton does support a public option for Obamacare, which is a government-sponsored insurance plan, she has consistently resisted the suggestion of a single-payer system and has stated that she would work to prevent the repeal of Obamacare and improve upon it.

During the vice presidential debate on October 5th, 2016, Tim Kaine claimed that Republicans, including Donald Trump, want to privatize Social Security. Kaine referenced Trump's book from 2000 where he called Social Security a Ponzi scheme and proposed allowing Americans to invest their payroll taxes in personal accounts. However, Kaine's claim is not entirely accurate as Trump has since stated his support for keeping Social Security as is without significant changes like private accounts. Therefore, Kaine's claim is mostly false.

During the vice presidential debate on October 5th, 2016, Tim Kaine claimed that Richard Nixon released his tax returns when he was under audit. This claim was in response to Mike Pence's statement that Donald Trump would release his tax returns once his audit was concluded. Kaine argued that Nixon's actions set a precedent for presidential candidates to release their tax returns. Fact-checkers found Kaine's claim to be true, as Nixon did release his tax returns while under audit in December 1973.
Kaine: Trump said undocumented immigrants 'will all be gone'

During the vice presidential debate on October 5th, 2016, Republican Mike Pence claimed that only 10 cents on the dollar from the Clinton Foundation goes to charitable causes. However, this claim is false. While it is true that the foundation gives a small fraction of its resources in grants, about 87 percent of its expenses go towards services it provides directly. The Clinton Foundation operates like a public charity and has been rated highly by experts in the field.

During the vice presidential debate on October 5th, 2016, Tim Kaine claimed that during President Barack Obama's tenure, the United States has created 15 million new jobs. This claim is partially true, as Kaine cherry-picked the time frame by starting the count at the low point in the job market, which was just over a year after Obama took office. If the count starts at the beginning of Obama's presidency, the number of jobs increased by 10.9 million, which is about two-thirds of the 15 million figure Kaine touted. Additionally, it is important to note that no elected official deserves full credit or blame for economic results, as other factors beyond their control also play a role.

During the vice presidential debate on October 5th, 2016, Mike Pence claimed that Iraq has been overrun by ISIS because Hillary Clinton failed to renegotiate a status of forces agreement. However, this claim is mostly false. While negotiations did fail, the key decisions and discussions took place between the White House and Iraqi leaders, not solely Clinton. The Obama administration wanted to protect American troops from legal action in Iraq, which was a sensitive issue in the Iraqi parliament. There is no evidence to suggest that the administration simply walked away from a deal to keep U.S. troops in Iraq. Therefore, the claim lacks key information and is misleading.
Mike Pence leaves out some details on his tax cu

During the 2016 vice presidential debate on October 5th, Republican Mike Pence claimed that Democrat Tim Kaine tried to raise taxes by about $4 billion during his time as Virginia governor from 2006 to 2010. Pence was referring to three unsuccessful tax proposals made by Kaine, including a plan to raise taxes for transportation and a proposal to raise state income tax rates. However, it should be noted that Kaine's 2009 income tax hike was offset by a $650 million cut in the state's car tax. Therefore, the net annual cost of all three tax and fee proposals was $3.35 billion. Pence's claim is mostly true, but his math double counts Kaine's unsuccessful efforts to raise taxes for transportation.

During the vice presidential debate on October 5th, 2016, Senator Tim Kaine claimed that both Donald Trump and Governor Mike Pence want to eliminate the federal minimum wage. While it is true that Trump has made conflicting statements about wages and the minimum wage, he has never explicitly called for its elimination. Pence, on the other hand, has a record of opposing minimum wage increases but has not called for its elimination either. Therefore, Kaine's claim is rated as half true.

-checking Rudy Giuliani on Meet the Press | Pund

CLAIM: Donald Trump claimed that Hillary Clinton gave up 20 percent of America's uranium supply to Russia.

EXPLANATION: In a campaign rally in 2016, Trump made this claim, which he reiterated in a press conference in 2017. The claim refers to a deal involving the Russian nuclear agency and a Toronto-based company called Uranium One. The deal allowed Russia to acquire a controlling stake in Uranium One, which owns mines, mills, and land in the United States, accounting for about 20 percent of the country's uranium production capacity. However, it is important to note that the 20 percent refers to capacity, not uranium that has been produced. The deal was approved by a committee composed of representatives from various U.S. government agencies, including the State Department, where Clinton was Secretary of State at the time. However, Clinton did not have the power to unilaterally approve or reject the deal, as it required the approval of multiple agencies and ultimately President Obama. Therefore, Trump's claim is mostly false.

During the October 19th, 2016 presidential debate, Clinton claimed that every major party nominee for the past 40 years, except for Donald Trump, has released their tax returns. This claim was made to the audience during the debate. Clinton's statement was rated as mostly true by fact-checkers, as the only exception to this claim was Gerald Ford, the Republican nominee in 1976.

During the first presidential debate on September 26th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that Clinton insiders, Patti Solis Doyle and Sidney Blumenthal, pushed the conspiracy theory that Barack Obama was not born in America. Trump pointed to an interview with Doyle on CNN where she mentioned a volunteer coordinator forwarding an email promoting the birther rumor. However, Doyle later clarified that she was referring to an email about Obama's religion, not his birthplace. As for Blumenthal, while he did contact a reporter at McClatchy to explore rumors about Obama's birthplace, there is no solid evidence that he questioned Obama's birthplace. Therefore, the claim made by Trump is false.

On September 26th, 2016, during the first presidential debate, Hillary Clinton claimed that Donald Trump has not paid any federal income tax. She suggested that Trump may be reluctant to release his tax returns because he doesn't want the American people to know that he hasn't paid taxes. However, this claim is mostly false. While the tax returns in question have not been released, a 1981 report from New Jersey gambling regulators shows that Trump did pay federal taxes for three out of five years, as verified by the Division of Gaming Enforcement. In the final two years, he did not pay federal income taxes due to significant losses in his business operations. Therefore, Clinton's statement ignores critical facts and is misleading.

During the third presidential debate on October 19th, 2016, Hillary Clinton claimed that Donald Trump was sued by the Justice Department in 1973 for racial discrimination because he refused to rent apartments to African-Americans. This claim is true. Trump, along with his father and their company, Trump Management, was sued under the Civil Rights Act for violating the Fair Housing Act by discriminating against tenants based on their race. The case was settled, and while Trump never admitted guilt, his company had to agree to measures to prevent future discrimination.

During the first presidential debate on September 26th, 2016, Hillary Clinton claimed that Donald Trump's tax plan would increase the national debt by over $5 trillion and raise taxes for some middle-class Americans. Independent experts, including Lily L. Batchelder, a professor at New York University Law School, confirmed that Clinton's statement accurately summarized their findings. Batchelder's analysis, along with the Tax Foundation and the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, supported Clinton's claim that Trump's plan would significantly increase the debt and disadvantage middle-class families compared to the wealthy. Additionally, Batchelder's research showed that Trump's plan would raise taxes for approximately 7.8 million families with minor children. The Tax Foundation also acknowledged that while taxpayers in all income groups would see more money, wealthier Americans would benefit more from Trump's plan. Overall, Clinton's statement was rated as true.

During the first presidential debate on September 26th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that there have been thousands of shootings in Chicago since January 1st. This claim was made in response to a question about how the candidates would address the racial divide in the country. Trump's campaign provided an article from Forbes that stated in 2015, 2,988 people were shot in Chicago, and as of September 8th, 2016, there had already been 2,949 shootings. The Chicago Tribune also confirmed these numbers, reporting that from January 1st to September 26th, 2016, there were 3,210 shooting victims. The Chicago Police Department data showed that there were 2,521 shooting incidents up to September 18th, 2016. While these numbers represent shootings and not necessarily homicides, experts confirmed that there has been an increase in gun violence in Chicago in recent years. However, they also noted that violent crime in Chicago is much lower than it was 20 years ago and that Chicago is not representative of crime in the entire United States. Therefore, Trump's claim that there have been thousands of shootings in Chicago is true.

During the second presidential debate on October 10th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that he did not support the war in Iraq prior to the 2003 invasion. However, the record does not support his assertion. Trump's comments around the time of the invasion were vague and he did not voice full-throated opposition until almost a year and a half after the invasion. Therefore, this claim is false.

On January 11th, 2017, during a press conference, Donald Trump claimed that Hillary Clinton was wrong in saying that he publicly invited Russian President Vladimir Putin to hack into American emails. Trump referred to a press conference he held on July 27th, 2016, where he said, "Russia, if you're listening, I hope you're able to find the 30,000 emails that are missing." However, Trump's campaign later stated that he was being sarcastic in his remarks. Fact-checkers rated Clinton's claim as half true, as Trump's statement referred specifically to Clinton's emails, not all American emails.

During the third presidential debate on October 19th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that Hillary Clinton called the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) the "gold standard" of trade deals. This claim was made in response to Clinton's defense that she had only supported the deal before it was finalized. Trump's claim is supported by Clinton's remarks in 2012, where she referred to the TPP as setting the "gold standard" in trade agreements. However, it is worth noting that Clinton later changed her position and opposed the deal after it was finalized. Therefore, Trump's statement is rated as mostly true.

During the first presidential debate at Hofstra University on September 26th, 2016, Hillary Clinton claimed that gun violence is the leading cause of death for young African American men, more than the next nine causes combined. This claim is accurate according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). In 2014, there were 2,256 gun-related homicides compared to 2,119 deaths in the next nine categories combined for African American men and boys between the ages of 15 and 24. When accidents and suicides related to guns are included, the gap between gun-related deaths and other types of deaths widens even further. However, it should be noted that this statement is dependent on the chosen age range and is not correct for African American boys between the ages of 10 and 14. Overall, Clinton's statement is accurate when defining "young" as being between the ages of 15 and 24, according to CDC data.

During the first presidential debate on September 26th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that his 92-page financial disclosure form provides a better understanding of his finances than his tax returns would. He argued that going to the Federal Elections Commission to see his financial disclosure form would reveal more about him than looking at his tax returns. However, experts disagree with this claim, stating that tax returns would provide valuable information about his effective tax rate, types of taxes paid, charitable giving, and a more detailed picture of his income-producing assets. Therefore, Trump's statement was deemed false.

During a debate on September 26th, 2016, Hillary Clinton claimed that Donald Trump believes climate change is a hoax perpetrated by the Chinese. Trump interrupted and denied ever saying that. However, it was found that Trump did tweet in 2012 that the concept of global warming was created by the Chinese. Trump has also called climate change a hoax in speeches, tweets, and media appearances. While he has described his remark as a joke, there is still some truth to Clinton's claim. Therefore, his statement is rated as mostly false.

During the first presidential debate on September 26th, 2016, Hillary Clinton claimed that Donald Trump had suggested negotiating down the national debt of the United States. Clinton's claim is supported by two separate interviews in May 2016, where Trump discussed the possibility of renegotiating and buying back debt at a discount. However, Trump later backtracked on his statements after facing criticism. Experts have stated that negotiating down the national debt would have severe consequences and is unlikely to be feasible. Overall, Clinton's claim is rated as mostly true.

On September 26th, 2016, during the first presidential debate, Hillary Clinton claimed that Donald Trump was one of the people who rooted for the housing crisis. She cited examples from 2006 to 2009 when Trump spoke optimistically about the opportunities created by falling real estate prices. While Trump did not welcome the tragedy of foreclosures, he did speak positively about the opportunities for investors like himself. Clinton's claim is mostly true, as it matches Trump's words, although it leaves out some nuance.

CLAIM: Donald Trump claimed at a rally in Kenansville, N.C. that African-American communities are in the worst shape they've ever been in before, stating that they have no education, no jobs, and are getting shot walking down the street.

EXPLANATION: Trump's statement lacks nuance and ignores the historical context of slavery and the Jim Crow era. Over the past half-century, African-Americans have made significant progress in areas such as life expectancy, educational attainment, and employment rates. While disparities still exist, the current situation is far from the worst it has ever been. The statement is rated as "pants on fire" false.
rick Murphy attacks Marco Rubio for voting against gun ban for people on no-fly list | PolitiFact Florid

During the second presidential debate on October 10th, 2016, Hillary Clinton claimed in a television ad that Democrats and Republicans working together were able to get Russia to cut their nuclear arms. She specifically mentioned the New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (New START) as the agreement between Russia and the United States that limited both countries' deployed strategic nuclear weapons. However, experts argue that Clinton's claim is imprecise and overstates the impact of the treaty. While New START does place tighter limits on deployed strategic weapons than previous treaties, Russia was already meeting most of the treaty's limits when it went into effect in 2011. Additionally, the treaty does not restrict either country from stockpiling weapons or require the destruction of existing weapons. Therefore, the claim is rated as half true.

On January 20th, 2017, during his inauguration, Donald Trump claimed that the United States spends more per student than almost any other major country in the world. This claim was rated as true by fact-checkers. According to data from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), Switzerland spends the most per student, followed by Norway and then the United States. While the US spends more per student than most countries, it does not translate into better performance, as American students' test scores are mediocre compared to other countries.

During the vice presidential debate on October 5th, 2016, Tim Kaine claimed that Donald Trump did not finish the birther controversy. Kaine argued that Trump continued to promote birtherism even after President Obama released his long-form birth certificate in 2011. Kaine supported his claim by citing Trump's tweets from 2011 to 2014, in which Trump either advocated for birtherism or expressed skepticism about Obama's birthplace. Kaine also pointed out that polls conducted after the release of Obama's birth certificate showed that a significant number of Americans still believed that Obama was born outside the United States. Therefore, Kaine concluded that Trump's claim of finishing the birther controversy was false.

During the second presidential debate on October 10th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that Hillary Clinton started the rumors questioning whether President Barack Obama was born in the United States. He referred to a press conference he held on September 16th, 2016, where he stated that Clinton and her campaign of 2008 started the birther controversy. However, fact-checkers have debunked this claim multiple times, as there is no evidence to support it. While Clinton supporters circulated the allegations during the 2008 Democratic primary, there is no record of Clinton or her campaign promoting the birther theory. Therefore, Trump's claim is false.

During the September 26th, 2016 debate, Tim Kaine claimed that Donald Trump allowed the late Libyan leader, Col. Moammar Gadhafi, to set up an elaborate tent at his estate in New York. Kaine stated that when Gadhafi was set to visit the United Nations and no one would let him stay in New York, Trump allowed him to set up the tent. This claim was rated as true, as it was confirmed that Gadhafi rented space at Trump's estate to put up his tent. Trump himself acknowledged this, although he framed it as a boast about how he snookered Gadhafi out of a lot of money.

During the third presidential debate on October 19th, 2016, Hillary Clinton claimed that Donald Trump's foundation took money from other people and used it to buy a six-foot-tall painting of himself. This claim was verified by reporter David Fahrenthold of The Washington Post, who found that the Trump Foundation had received most of its funds from sources other than Trump himself. Fahrenthold also confirmed the anecdote about the painting with the artist who created it. Therefore, Clinton's claim was rated as true.

On October 10th, 2016, during the second presidential debate, Donald Trump claimed that the heroin epidemic in suburban white communities is tied to weak borders and illegal immigration. He argued that heroin, which has seen a significant increase in overdoses, is entering the United States largely through the southern border. This claim is supported by data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration, and the White House, which all confirm that the majority of heroin in the United States comes from Mexico and South America. Therefore, Trump's claim is rated as true.

On September 26th, 2016, during the first presidential debate, Donald Trump claimed that Barack Obama had doubled the national debt during his time in office. Trump justified his statement by referring to figures from the U.S. Treasury Department, which showed that the national debt was $10.6 trillion when Obama took office in 2009 and had risen to $19.5 trillion by September 6th, 2016. Trump's estimate that the debt would be close to $20 trillion by the end of Obama's term is reasonable. However, it is important to note that the rise in the debt was not solely Obama's responsibility, as Congress had to approve the spending bills. Additionally, the recession that began before Obama took office also contributed to the increase in debt. Therefore, Trump's claim is rated as half true.

During the third presidential debate on October 19th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that veterans are being treated worse than immigrants living illegally in the United States. He made this claim at various events, including a rally honoring prisoners of war and troops missing in action, a speech outlining his immigration plan, and a speech at the Union League of Philadelphia. The Trump campaign argued that politicians, including Hillary Clinton, give more attention and support to those in the country illegally than to veterans. However, fact-checkers found that veterans have access to education, healthcare, and tax benefits that undocumented immigrants do not have. Therefore, the claim made by Trump is false.

During the vice presidential debate on October 5th, 2016, Tim Kaine claimed that Donald Trump's statement about Russian President Vladimir Putin calling him "brilliant" was mostly false. Kaine referred to a fact-checking article that stated the word Putin used was "yarkii," which means bright or colorful in Russian, not intelligent or clever. The article concluded that Trump's claim was imprecise and rated it as mostly false.

During a debate on September 26th, 2016, Hillary Clinton claimed that Donald Trump extensively supported the attacks that toppled Libyan dictator Muammar Gadhafi. She argued that there was no difference between herself and Trump on the Libyan action. Clinton supported her claim by referencing a video from Trump's own video blog in which he stated, "We should go in, we should stop this guy." Although there were not many comments from Trump about Libya, the few that were found showed his support for intervention. Therefore, Clinton's claim was rated mostly true.

During the NBC commander in chief forum on September 7th, 2016, Hillary Clinton claimed that none of the emails she sent or received had a header indicating that they were classified. While it is true that none of her emails had a header, it is important to note that the absence of a header does not mean that the information was not classified. The FBI found 81 email chains on Clinton's private server that contained classified information, although they were not properly labeled. Therefore, Clinton's claim is mostly true, but it needs additional context to fully understand the situation.

During the NBC commander in chief forum on September 7th, 2016, Hillary Clinton claimed that her opponent, Donald Trump, supports privatizing the Veterans Affairs (VA) health care system. She stated that she would not let the VA be privatized and that she believed there was an agenda to do so supported by Trump. However, fact-checkers found that Trump does not support privatizing the system but rather allowing veterans to have access to private providers when facing delays at the VA. While Clinton's statement contains some truth, it ignores critical facts and is therefore rated as mostly false.

During the NBC commander-in-chief forum on September 7th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that Hillary Clinton said the veterans affairs scandal is overexaggerated and that she was satisfied with what was going on. However, this claim is misleading and leaves out important context. While Clinton did say that the problems at the VA have not been as widespread as portrayed, she also acknowledged systemic issues and repeatedly called for reform to ensure veterans receive timely care. Therefore, Trump's statement is rated as mostly false.

CLAIM: During the 3rd presidential debate on October 19th, 2016, Hillary Clinton claimed that Donald Trump initially supported the war in Iraq.

EXPLANATION: In response to a question about her own vote in favor of the Iraq war, Clinton pointed out that Trump had initially supported the war. Trump denied this claim during the debate, stating that he was "totally against the war in Iraq." However, evidence from interviews and statements made by Trump before the invasion of Iraq contradicts his claim of being against the war. Trump's statements at the time indicated some level of acceptance or support for military action, even if he later criticized the handling of the war. Therefore, Clinton's claim that Trump initially supported the war in Iraq is deemed false.

During the vice presidential debate on October 5th, 2016, Republican strategist Alex Castellanos claimed that the Clinton Foundation gives less than 10 percent of its money in direct aid. However, this claim is misleading because it does not take into account the bulk of the foundation's work. While grantmaking is not part of its mission, the foundation spends a significant amount of money on its own in-house programs, which accounted for about 80 percent of its expenses in 2013. Therefore, Castellanos' claim is rated as mostly false.

During the third presidential debate on October 19th, 2016, Donald Trump's running mate, Mike Pence, claimed that Hillary Clinton wants to increase Syrian refugees to the United States by 550 percent. This claim is accurate, as Clinton had previously supported allowing in 65,000 refugees, while Obama supported a figure of 10,000. However, it is important to note that these numbers applied to fiscal year 2016 and Clinton has not discussed numbers for the next fiscal year. Additionally, there is a screening process for refugees, with the UN identifying and screening them before they are referred to a country for resettlement. U.S. security agencies also conduct multiple security checks. Therefore, Pence's claim is deemed true.

During the vice presidential debate on October 5th, 2016, Mike Pence claimed that Hillary Clinton has pledged amnesty in her first 100 days and that her plan will provide Obamacare, Social Security, and Medicare for illegal immigrants, breaking the federal budget. However, Clinton has not pledged amnesty in her first 100 days, but rather promised to introduce comprehensive immigration reform with a pathway to full and equal citizenship. While Clinton does support allowing certain immigrants to stay in the US and be temporarily free from deportation, this does not constitute amnesty. Additionally, Clinton's plan does not provide Obamacare, Social Security, and Medicare to immigrants, as they would have to pay into the system like everyone else. It would take at least a decade, if not longer, for them to be eligible for Social Security and Medicare benefits. Furthermore, even if all 11 million undocumented immigrants were eligible for Medicaid, it would not break the federal budget. Therefore, Pence's statement is mostly false.

CLAIM: Donald Trump claimed that since 2013, the Obama administration has allowed 300,000 criminal aliens to return back into United States communities.

EXPLANATION: Trump's claim is based on an estimate provided by Jessica M. Vaughan, the director of policy studies with the Center for Immigration Studies. The estimate includes three categories: 86,288 criminal aliens released from custody pending removal proceedings, 18,646 requests by ICE to hold deportable aliens denied by state and local law enforcement agencies, and over 200,000 criminal aliens let off by ICE officers due to prosecutorial discretion. However, experts have raised concerns about the accuracy of the 200,000 figure, as it relies heavily on Vaughan's calculations of ICE data, which can be opaque and hard to obtain. Additionally, there is a dispute over the definition of "criminal aliens" and whether the Obama administration's prioritization of removal proceedings is driven by political considerations or resource constraints. Overall, the claim is rated as half true.

CLAIM: Donald Trump claimed that at least 23 countries refuse to take their people back after they've been ordered to leave the United States, including large numbers of violent criminals.

EXPLANATION: Trump's claim is accurate, as the figure of 23 countries comes from a U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement document. These countries, such as Afghanistan, Algeria, China, Cuba, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, and Zimbabwe, are considered recalcitrant in taking back their citizens. However, the claim about large numbers of violent criminals is harder to verify, as the data shows that traffic or drug-related offenses are more common among illegal immigrants. While there were some convictions for violent offenses, they make up a smaller percentage overall. Therefore, Trump's claim is mostly true.

CLAIM: Donald Trump claimed that the number of undocumented immigrants in the United States could be as low as 3 million or as high as 30 million.

EXPLANATION: Trump has questioned the commonly cited estimate of 11 million undocumented immigrants in the past, and in his recent speech on immigration, he reiterated his doubts about this number. However, experts from various organizations that study immigration have stated that Trump's claim is inaccurate. The Department of Homeland Security estimated the undocumented immigrant population at 11.4 million in 2012, and other independent organizations have provided similar figures. These estimates are based on subtracting known legal immigrants from the total number of foreign-born people documented in the U.S. census. Experts argue that there is no evidence to support Trump's claim of 3 million or 30 million undocumented immigrants, and they consider these figures to be virtually impossible. The experts also explain that the 11 million estimate has remained consistent because of the continuous flow of undocumented immigrants entering and leaving the country. Therefore, Trump's claim is rated as "pants on fire" false.

Donald Trump claimed in a speech in Arizona that illegal immigration costs the United States more than $113 billion a year. He cited a 2013 report from the Federation for American Immigration Reform (FAIR) as the source of this data. However, the report's estimates are based on broad assumptions and have been criticized for their lack of accuracy. Other reports from pro-immigration or neutral groups have estimated the costs to be significantly lower. Therefore, Trump's claim is rated as mostly false.

During the vice presidential debate on October 5th, 2016, Mike Pence claimed that the Clinton Foundation spends about 80 percent of its donations on overhead and only 20 percent on charitable work. While only a small portion of the donations are awarded as grants, the Clinton Foundation actually spends between 80-90 percent on program services, which is the standard in the industry for defining charitable work. Hillary Clinton claimed during the third presidential debate on October 19th, 2016 that her campaign platform includes the biggest investment in new, good-paying jobs since World War II. She proposed total federal spending of at least $900 billion over a 10-year period in areas such as infrastructure, higher education, energy and research, and housing. While her proposed investment is larger than any other 10-year investment since World War II, when considering the size of historical public investments as a share of GDP, there have been 12 years with larger public investments. Additionally, it is uncertain whether these investments will result in new, good-paying jobs as it depends on predictions and the effectiveness of the proposed programs. Therefore, Clinton's claim is rated as half true.

During the vice presidential debate on October 5th, 2016, Mike Pence claimed that Americans are paying higher taxes under President Barack Obama. He supported this claim by citing a list of tax hikes enacted under Obama, including levies on tobacco products and taxes to fund healthcare reforms. However, experts have pointed out that there haven't been many major tax changes during Obama's term, and the tax burden on households has actually remained relatively stable. While Obama did raise some taxes, he also extended tax cuts and enacted temporary tax cuts to stimulate the economy. Therefore, Pence's claim is rated as half true.

During a campaign speech in Youngstown, Ohio on September 26th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that NATO had changed their policy and created a new division focused on terror threats in response to his previous comments that NATO was obsolete. However, experts have found very little accuracy in this statement. While NATO did create a new division for coordinating intelligence sharing, this change was not significant and had been in the works before Trump's comments. Furthermore, NATO has been involved in counterterrorism efforts since 1980 and invoked Article 5 after the 9/11 attacks. Experts also noted that NATO's structure and role have made it an imperfect vehicle for counterterrorism. Overall, there is no evidence to support Trump's claim that NATO changed their policy in response to his comments, and experts believe that the change was not influenced by him. Therefore, Trump's statement is false.

Donald Trump claimed that the U.S. election system is rigged and cited examples of voter fraud to support his claim. However, experts have stated that voter fraud is extremely rare, often unintentional, and not on a scale large enough to affect a national election. While there are isolated cases of bought local elections, it is unlikely to be replicated on a national scale. Additionally, there is no evidence of deliberate malfeasance altering any election through tampering with electronic voting machines. Therefore, Trump's claim is deemed false.

During the vice presidential debate on October 5th, 2016, Tim Kaine claimed that Donald Trump had characterized the United States military as a disaster. Kaine stated that Trump had made this comment during the sixth GOP primary debate on January 14th, 2016. Fact-checking confirmed that Trump did indeed use the phrase "our military is a disaster" during that debate. While Trump has more recently used the term "depleted" to describe the military, Kaine's claim was deemed mostly true.

During the vice presidential debate on October 5th, 2016, Mike Pence claimed that Hillary Clinton's statement about putting a lid on Iran's nuclear program was mostly true. He argued that while there are uncertainties about the long-term effectiveness of the nuclear agreement, most independent experts agree that it is effective on paper and close to the best outcome achieved through diplomatic means. Pence acknowledged that there are no guarantees, but stated that Clinton's claim is plausible if "putting a lid on" is defined as keeping the program in check rather than ensuring it will never happen.

On January 20th, 2017, during his inauguration, Donald Trump claimed that illegal immigration and the crime rate in the United States are at their highest in decades. However, fact-checking shows that this claim is mostly false. The number of apprehensions by the U.S. Border Patrol has been steadily declining, and the overall crime rate has been decreasing since the early 1990s. While there may be a slight recent uptick in crime based on preliminary data, the overall trend contradicts Trump's claim.

CLAIM: Donald Trump games the U.S. visa system to hire temporary foreign workers at low wages.

EXPLANATION: During the Democratic National Convention, former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg accused Donald Trump of being a hypocrite on immigration. Bloomberg claimed that while Trump wants to deport millions of undocumented immigrants, he also takes advantage of the visa system to hire foreign workers at his properties. Trump has sought H-2B visas for low-skilled, low-wage workers at his Mar-a-Lago club in Florida. Critics argue that these visas allow employers to exploit foreign workers, while employers argue that they need these workers to fill jobs that Americans don't want. Trump has defended his use of these visas, stating that he is following the laws and regulations. The claim that Trump games the visa system is considered mostly true.

On October 19th, 2016, during the third presidential debate, Chris Wallace claimed that Donald Trump's comments about punishing women for having abortions were contradictory. Wallace referenced a conversation between Trump and MSNBC's Chris Matthews on March 30, 2016, where Trump initially stated that there should be some form of punishment for women who have abortions. However, Trump quickly walked back his comments and clarified that he meant doctors should be punished, not women. Wallace rated Barbara Boxer's claim that Trump said women should be punished for exercising their right to choose as half true, as it left out important details and did not acknowledge Trump's clarification.

CLAIM: Donald Trump claimed that he would bring back manufacturing jobs to the United States, but many of his own Trump-branded products are made overseas.

EXPLANATION: During a Funny or Die video shown at the Democratic National Convention, actor Ken Jeong and former White House economist Austan Goolsbee pointed out that Trump-branded products such as shirts, neckties, suits, cufflinks, vodka, and glassware are made in countries like Bangladesh, China, Mexico, the Netherlands, and Slovenia. While some Trump products are made in the United States, the claim that many of them are made overseas is mostly true.

CLAIM: Donald Trump claimed that an analysis showed that Bernie Sanders would have won the Democratic nomination if it were not for the superdelegates.

EXPLANATION: Trump's claim is false. Even without superdelegates, Sanders would have still lost the nomination because Clinton won the majority of the popular vote and pledged delegates. The only way for Sanders to have won is if he could have persuaded more superdelegates to switch their votes from Clinton to him.

During his nomination acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention on July 21st, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that nearly 180,000 illegal immigrants with criminal records, who had been ordered deported, were roaming free to threaten peaceful citizens. This claim was based on a report from the Center for Immigration Studies, which relied on data obtained by the Senate Judiciary Committee. The report stated that as of July 2015, there were over 925,000 immigrants who had been ordered removed but were still in the country, and an estimated 20% of them had at least one criminal conviction. While Trump's numbers are accurate, experts point out that there is important context to consider. Some of these immigrants come from countries that refuse to accept them back, so they have to be released after completing their sentences. Additionally, some state and local jurisdictions have policies that limit cooperation with immigration authorities, so they do not notify them when a deportable noncitizen has completed a jail term or prison sentence. Immigration officials also make custody determinations on a case-by-case basis, and those who do not pose a threat to the community may be placed on some form of supervision as an alternative to detention. Overall, Trump's statement is accurate but needs additional information, so it is rated as mostly true.

In his acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention on July 21st, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that an amendment pushed by Lyndon Johnson threatens religious institutions with a loss of their tax-exempt status if they openly advocate their political views. This claim is true. The restriction is actually a law, not an amendment, and it applies to all nonprofit charitable organizations, not just religious institutions. The law prohibits these organizations from directly or indirectly participating in or intervening in any political campaign on behalf of or in opposition to any candidate for elective public office. Violating this restriction could result in the revocation of the organization's tax-exempt status and the imposition of taxes. However, nonpartisan, unbiased voter education activities are allowed. Trump's statement is accurate, although it is important to note that the prohibition applies to all nonprofit organizations, not just religious institutions.

During the second presidential debate on October 10th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that the United States is one of the highest-taxed nations in the world. While he slightly tempered his language from previous statements, this claim is still mostly false. Trump did not specify that he was referring to the corporate tax rate, which is higher than most industrialized nations. However, when considering overall tax burden, the United States is not one of the highest-taxed nations. Therefore, the claim is misleading and lacks accuracy.

On July 21st, 2016, during his acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention, Donald Trump claimed that household incomes are down more than $4,000 since the year 2000. This claim is accurate, as median household income fell from $57,724 in 2000 to $53,657 in 2014, adjusted for inflation. However, it is worth noting that the majority of this decline occurred during the presidency of George W. Bush, a Republican. Since Obama took office, household incomes have fallen by $1,656. Therefore, while Trump's statement is true, it needs additional context, so it is rated as mostly true.

During the second presidential debate on October 10th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that the United States had a trade deficit in goods of nearly $800 billion in the previous year. According to census data, the trade deficit in goods for 2015 was $763 billion, which is reasonably close to Trump's claim. Therefore, the fact-checkers rated Trump's claim as true.
Donald Trump's largely accurate about Clinton's past support for NAFTA, T

On July 21st, 2016, during the Trump draft RNC, Donald Trump claimed that his opponent, Hillary Clinton, wants to essentially abolish the Second Amendment. However, there is no evidence that Clinton has ever explicitly stated or suggested that she wants to abolish the Second Amendment. While she has called for stronger gun control measures, she has consistently affirmed her support for the right to bear arms. Some gun rights advocates argue that Clinton's comments on gun control imply a desire to roll back the Second Amendment, but this is a matter of interpretation. Overall, Trump's claim is false.

During his acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention on July 21st, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that Hillary Clinton plans a "massive" tax increase, while he has proposed the largest tax reduction of any candidate running for president. The claim is mostly true. The Urban Institute-Brookings Institution Tax Policy Center estimates that Clinton's proposed tax hikes would primarily affect the highest earners, with the top 5 percent of taxpayers experiencing an average reduction of less than 1 percent in after-tax income. On the other hand, Trump's tax cuts would be the largest of any candidate, with the average tax cuts for the top 1 percent being 17.5 percent of after-tax income. However, economists are skeptical about the sustainability of Trump's tax cuts, as they would require significant cuts to federal spending or an increase in debt.

On July 21st, 2016, during the Trump draft RNC, Donald Trump claimed that America has lost nearly one third of its manufacturing jobs since 1997 due to disastrous trade deals supported by Bill and Hillary Clinton. Trump specifically blamed the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) and China's entry into the World Trade Organization for the loss of jobs. While the numbers are accurate, the impact of the trade deals on manufacturing jobs is more complex. While NAFTA likely had little impact on jobs, there is broad agreement that China's entry into the WTO resulted in the loss of millions of American manufacturing jobs. However, economists do not attribute the entire number of jobs lost to either trade deal. Additionally, Trump's claim that the trade deals and their alleged failures are solely the fault of the Clintons overlooks the role played by Republicans in supporting these deals. Overall, the claim is rated as half true.

During the vice presidential debate on October 5th, 2016, Mike Pence claimed that Hillary Clinton supports sanctuary cities. He referenced a statement made by Donald Trump at the Republican convention, where Trump criticized Clinton for favoring shielding undocumented immigrants from federal laws. Pence argued that sanctuary cities, which limit their assistance to federal immigration officials, harm the federal government's ability to enforce immigration laws and give some undocumented immigrants a pass. He also mentioned a case in San Francisco where a man who had been deported multiple times was released from jail and later charged with murder. Pence's claim was rated mostly true by Politifact.

On July 21st, 2016, during his acceptance speech for the Republican presidential nomination, Donald Trump claimed that Hillary Clinton has called for a "radical 550 percent increase in Syrian refugees" and that there is no way to screen these refugees to find out who they are or where they come from. The fact-checking analysis states that the 550 percent figure is correct, but it is incorrect to suggest that there is no screening process for Syrian refugees. The refugees undergo an extensive screening process that includes referrals, interviews, background checks, medical screenings, and security clearances, which can take up to two years or longer. The claim is rated as half true.

In his speech accepting the Republican presidential nomination on July 21st, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that 43 million Americans are on food stamps. This claim was fact-checked and found to be true. The U.S. Department of Agriculture reported that in April 2016, there were almost 43.6 million people receiving SNAP benefits, the lowest level since October 2010. However, it is important to note that the number of participants has been decreasing in recent years due to the economic recovery.

On July 21st, 2016, during his speech accepting the Republican party nomination for president, Donald Trump claimed that the number of new illegal immigrant families who have crossed the border so far in that year already exceeded the entire total from 2015. According to U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) statistics, if interpreted by fiscal year (October 1 to September 30), Trump's claim is correct. However, if interpreted by calendar year (January 1 to December 31), his claim is incorrect. Therefore, the claim is rated as half true.

CLAIM: Donald Trump claimed that ISIS was not an issue before Hillary Clinton served as Secretary of State.

SUMMARY: During the Republican National Convention on July 21st, 2016, Donald Trump stated that ISIS was not a problem before Hillary Clinton's tenure as Secretary of State. However, experts have pointed out that ISIS existed under a different name before Clinton's time, and there were various factors that contributed to its rise, including the intervention in Libya and the Iraq invasion.

EXPLANATION: Donald Trump made the claim during the Republican National Convention that ISIS was not a concern before Hillary Clinton became Secretary of State. However, experts have refuted this claim, stating that ISIS existed under a different name before Clinton's tenure. They also pointed out that there were multiple factors that contributed to the rise of ISIS, including the intervention in Libya and the Iraq invasion, both of which Clinton had some involvement in. Therefore, the claim made by Trump is considered mostly false.

On July 21st, 2016, during his speech accepting the Republican nomination, Donald Trump claimed that homicides in America's 50 largest cities increased by 17% last year, which he stated was the largest increase in 25 years. This claim was based on calculations made by The Washington Post. However, Trump ignored the cautionary notes in the same article, which stated that there was no single explanation for the increases and no clear pattern among the cities that experienced the most violence. The article also noted that other data showed a more modest increase in violent offenses nationally. Criminologists cautioned against making too much of changes in data over a single year and emphasized the importance of looking at long-term trends, which show that violent crime has been consistently falling for about a quarter century. Therefore, Trump's claim was rated as half true.

In his speech accepting the Republican nomination for president at the party's national convention in Cleveland on July 21st, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that "two million more Latinos are in poverty today than when the president took his oath of office less than eight years ago." While it is true that there has been an increase of about 2 million Hispanic people living in poverty since 2008, this statistic is misleading because the Hispanic population has also grown during this time. The poverty rate among Hispanics has remained relatively stable throughout Obama's presidency, hovering just above 23 percent. Therefore, Trump's claim is rated as half true.

During the 2016 presidential debate, Donald Trump claimed that Hillary Clinton "invented" ISIS with her policies. However, this claim is inaccurate. The roots of ISIS trace back to 2004, before Clinton was Secretary of State. While Clinton did support the intervention in Libya, which gave ISIS an opening, it is misleading to solely blame her for the rise of ISIS. There were several factors that contributed to the growth of ISIS, including decisions made by both the Bush and Obama administrations. Therefore, Trump's claim that Clinton is responsible for ISIS is false.

CLAIM: Donald Trump claimed that Hillary Clinton is for open borders.

EXPLANATION: During the Republican convention, former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani defended Donald Trump's plan to secure the border and claimed that Hillary Clinton would take the opposite approach. While Clinton's plan would make it easier for many undocumented immigrants to avoid deportation, it does not mean open borders or ending enforcement. Therefore, the claim made by Donald Trump is false.

During the NBC commander in chief forum on September 7th, 2016, Clinton claimed that recent research by the VA supports Trump's statement that "a shocking 20 veterans are committing suicide each and every day, especially our older veterans." The VA's research, based on records from every state, found that in 2014, 7,403 veterans took their own lives, averaging about 20 veterans a day. The research also showed that 65% of veterans who committed suicide in 2014 were 50 or older, aligning with Trump's statement about older veterans being particularly affected. The VA concluded that veterans have a 21% higher risk of suicide than non-serving adults.

During a rally in Phoenix on June 18th, 2016, Donald Trump accused Hillary Clinton of receiving tens of millions of dollars from countries that mistreat women and kill gay people. He specifically referenced donations given to the Clinton Foundation. While it is true that the Clinton Foundation has received donations from countries with poor records on human rights, it is important to note that political candidates cannot accept money from foreign governments. Therefore, Trump's claim that Clinton personally received money from these countries is an oversimplification. However, the claim is rated as half true because the Clinton Foundation did receive donations from these countries both before and after Clinton's tenure as Secretary of State.

During the NBC commander in chief forum on September 7th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that he received the highest vote count in the history of the Republican Party primary system. However, it is worth noting that Trump also holds the record for the most votes cast against a primary candidate, and he was supported by less than half of the Republican Party's primary voters. Therefore, while Trump's claim is accurate, it lacks important context, and is rated as mostly true.

On August 3rd, 2017, Donald Trump claimed that Hillary Clinton's State Department approved the transfer of 20 percent of America's uranium holdings to Russia, while nine investors in the deal funneled $145 million to the Clinton Foundation. However, this claim is mostly false. While the State Department did approve Russia's gradual takeover of a company with U.S. uranium assets, it was not a unilateral decision and required approval from multiple government agencies. Additionally, most of the donations to the Clinton Foundation occurred before the Russian deal, and there is no evidence of a quid pro quo. Therefore, Trump's claim exaggerates the links and is unsubstantiated.

During a rally in Ohio, Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton criticized her opponent, Donald Trump, by claiming that he called pregnancy an inconvenience for business owners. Studies have shown that the costs of accommodating pregnant employees are minimal, and the positive gains outweigh any costs.

During the vice presidential debate on October 5th, 2016, Mike Pence claimed that Hillary Clinton's immigration platform would create "totally open borders" for the United States. However, this claim is false. Clinton has supported legislation that includes a path to citizenship with conditions and heightened border security. While she does want to make it easier for undocumented immigrants to stay in the country, this does not mean she wants to end all enforcement or create open borders. Clinton's plan calls for protecting the border and targeting deportation to criminals and security threats. Therefore, Pence's claim is a distortion of Clinton's proposals.

During a speech on June 22nd, 2016, Donald Trump accused Hillary Clinton of trying to delete her past support for the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal. He claimed that she had deleted the record of her support from her book. However, there is no evidence that Trump's comments influenced Clinton's stance on the treaty, and Clinton had already expressed support for the deal in 2012. In her book, "Hard Choices," Clinton discussed the importance of the TPP and its potential benefits for American workers. While a small reference to the TPP was removed in the paperback edition of the book, the pages discussing its importance were not deleted. Therefore, Trump's claim that Clinton deleted her support for the TPP from her book is false.
Did Google adjust its autocomplete algorithm to hide Hillary Clinton's problems? | Pund

Loretta Lynch says gays and lesbians are most frequently targeted for hate crimes | PolitiFact Florid

On June 22nd, 2016, Donald Trump claimed during a speech at Trump NY Soho that Hillary Clinton slept through the Benghazi attack and was not available to answer the proverbial 3 a.m. phone call. However, this claim is false. The attack took place at around 9:30 p.m. Benghazi time, or 3:30 p.m. Washington time, and Clinton was at her State Department office. None of the congressional investigations into the attacks have faulted Clinton for her actions that day, and there is no evidence to support the claim that she was asleep during the attack.

On June 22nd, 2016, at Trump NY Soho, Donald Trump claimed that Hillary Clinton wants to spend hundreds of billions of dollars on refugees, and with that money, America could rebuild every inner city. However, the Trump campaign did not provide any supporting numbers for this claim. The Obama administration's budget request for FY 2017 is about $2.2 billion for refugees, and even if Clinton were to double or triple that amount, it would still be nowhere near the hundreds of billions Trump claimed. Additionally, the estimated cost to rebuild America's inner cities is over $225 billion, making Trump's numbers significantly off. This claim is rated as "pants on fire."

During the Sanders Cruz healthcare debate on February 7th, 2017, Bernie Sanders claimed that Donald Trump's statement about Obamacare causing an increase in part-time jobs is false. Sanders argued that while some research suggests a small uptick in part-time work due to the Affordable Care Act, neither the data nor experts on both sides of the political spectrum support Trump's claim. Therefore, Sanders rated Trump's claim as false.

On June 22nd, 2016, Donald Trump claimed during a speech in New York that Hillary Clinton lied about landing in Bosnia under sniper fire and that the attack turned out to be young girls handing her flowers. Trump's claim is supported by evidence, as Clinton did make the false claim in 2008 but later retracted it. The only minor error in Trump's statement is that Clinton was handed a poem, not flowers. Overall, Trump's claim is rated as true.

In a speech on June 22nd, 2016, at Trump NY Soho, Donald Trump claimed that he was among the earliest to criticize the rush to war in Iraq, even before the war started. However, fact-checking reveals that there is no evidence to support this claim. The earliest example found was a September 2002 interview where Trump expressed support for the invasion. Trump's harshest criticism of the war came more than a year into the conflict. Therefore, Trump's claim is false.

During the September 26th, 2016 debate, Hillary Clinton claimed that Donald Trump had bankrupted his companies four times. This claim is accurate, as Trump has actually filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy six times - four times in the 1990s, once in 2004, and once in 2009. However, experts argue that Trump should not bear all the responsibility for these bankruptcies, as they were largely a result of the struggling casino industry at the time. Therefore, Clinton's claim is rated as mostly true.

CLAIM: During the October 19th, 2016 presidential debate, Hillary Clinton claimed that 9 million people have lower-cost HIV/AIDS medicine thanks to the efforts of the Clinton Foundation and her husband.

EXPLANATION: The Clinton Foundation, specifically the Clinton Health Access Initiative, has been working since 2002 to reduce the cost of HIV/AIDS treatment through bulk-buying and negotiating with drug companies. The World Health Organization has recognized the Clinton Health Access Initiative as one of the organizations collaborating to ensure a steady supply of affordable drugs. The initiative has been successful in lowering production costs and drug prices, resulting in a significant decrease in the cost of HIV/AIDS medicine. The total number of patients benefiting from the initiative is 11.8 million, according to a spokesperson. Therefore, Clinton's claim that 9 million people have lower-cost HIV/AIDS medicine is true and even understates the actual number of beneficiaries.

On June 22nd, 2016, Donald Trump claimed during a speech attacking Hillary Clinton at Trump NY Soho that the mass shooting in an Orlando nightclub is evidence that the United States needs to restrict the number of foreigners coming into the country. He argued that refugees are potential terrorists and criticized the government for admitting increasing numbers of refugees without an effective security plan. Trump claimed that Clinton plans to massively increase admissions, including a 500 percent increase in Syrian refugees, without a screening plan. However, Clinton has stated that refugees would have to go through a rigorous vetting process before being admitted. The claim is mostly true but needs clarification.
Hillary Clinton criticizes Fla. gun laws after Orlando mass shooting | PolitiFact Florid

During the second presidential debate on October 10th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that there is no system to vet refugees from the Middle East. He equated refugee admission to a bigger version of the Trojan Horse and criticized Hillary Clinton's plan to admit hundreds of thousands of refugees without an effective screening system. However, this claim is false. The vetting process for refugees has been in place since 1980 and involves multiple federal intelligence and security agencies, as well as the United Nations. It typically takes one to two years and includes numerous rounds of security checks. While there are concerns about information gaps, there is indeed a system to vet refugees from the Middle East.
Donald Trump correct that U.S. gives 100,000 green cards a year to migrants from Middle Eas

During the second presidential debate on October 10th, 2016, Hillary Clinton claimed that Donald Trump mocked a disabled news reporter. Clinton's claim was based on an ad produced by a super PAC backing her campaign, which featured an Ohio couple discussing their daughter who was born with a spinal defect. The ad showed a photo of the reporter, Serge Kovaleski, who has a congenital condition that limits the movement of his joints, and a video clip of Trump at a rally appearing to physically mimic Kovaleski's disability. Clinton argued that Trump's behavior showed his lack of empathy and respect for people with disabilities.

On September 1st, 2016, during a debate on immigration in Phoenix, Donald Trump claimed that President Obama has said that the top national security threat facing America is global warming. Obama has consistently emphasized that defeating terrorism is his most urgent priority. Therefore, Trump's claim is an exaggeration and ignores important context.

On January 26th, 2017, during a debate, Donald Trump claimed that waterboarding is an effective interrogation technique. However, experts argue that there is no irrefutable evidence to support this claim. WHO: Hillary Clinton
CLAIM: Under Donald Trump's tax plan, the top 0.1 percent of taxpayers would receive more tax relief than the bottom 60 percent of taxpayers combined.
EXPLANATION: Clinton's claim is supported by a report from the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center, which found that under Trump's plan, the highest-income households would receive the largest tax cuts, both in dollars and as a percentage of income. Specifically, the top 0.1 percent of taxpayers, who earn over $3.7 million per year, would receive an average tax cut of more than $1.3 million in 2017. This group would receive 18 percent of the tax reduction, while the bottom 60 percent of taxpayers would receive 16.4 percent of the reduction.

On January 26th, 2017, during a debate with Chuck Todd on ABC, Donald Trump claimed that same-day voter registration makes it easier for noncitizens to vote. However, election experts have stated that there is no increased risk of noncitizens voting in states with same-day registration compared to states that require voters to register in advance. Same-day registration states have safeguards in place, such as requiring proper identification and proof of residency, to ensure that only eligible citizens can vote. Therefore, Trump's claim is false.

CLAIM: Donald Trump claimed in an interview with NBC's Meet the Press on May 8, 2016, that the United States is the highest taxed nation in the world.

EXPLANATION: Trump's claim is false. When comparing the United States to other industrialized nations, data from 2014 shows that the United States is not the most highly taxed country. In terms of corporate tax rates, the United States does have one of the highest top marginal rates, but companies pay less in practice due to deductions and exclusions. When looking at the actual tax burden on U.S. companies, it is far from the highest in the world. Therefore, Trump's claim is inaccurate.

George Clooney claimed on Meet the Press that the overwhelming amount of money being raised at fundraisers for Hillary Clinton is not going to her campaign, but rather to congressmen and senators in an effort to take back Congress. While it is true that most of the big-dollar donations are not going directly to Clinton's campaign, they are not necessarily going to congressmen and senators either. The money is primarily going to the Democratic National Committee (DNC), which uses it for campaign infrastructure that benefits both Clinton and other Democratic candidates. Therefore, Clooney's claim is partially accurate but lacks important details.

CLAIM: Donald Trump claimed in a Trump Times interview on March 23rd, 2017 that Rafael Cruz, the father of Ted Cruz, was with Lee Harvey Oswald before the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.

EXPLANATION: Trump's claim is based on a National Enquirer report that alleges Rafael Cruz is the man standing next to Oswald in a photo from 1963. However, technical experts have stated that the photo is too grainy to make a conclusive identification. Historians of the period also say there is no evidence to suggest that Cruz and Oswald had any association. Therefore, Trump's claim is considered implausible and ridiculous by experts, and it is rated as "pants on fire" by Politifact.

During the NBC commander in chief forum on September 7th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that when President Obama landed in Cuba on Air Force One, no leader was there to greet him, which he described as an unprecedented incident in the history of Air Force One. While it is true that neither Fidel Castro nor Raul Castro, the leaders of Cuba, were present at the airport, Trump's claim is not entirely accurate. The Cuban Foreign Minister and other high-ranking officials were there to greet President Obama. Additionally, there is a precedent for the foreign minister greeting a visiting president, as seen during President Nixon's trip to China in 1972. Therefore, the claim is rated as half true.
LeBron James pays Social Security taxes before halftime of first game, U.S. Rep. Alan Grayson says | PolitiFact Florid

During the second presidential debate on October 10th, 2016, Donald Trump claimed that ISIS is making millions of dollars a week selling Libyan oil. However, security experts and news reports strongly disagree with this claim. They acknowledge that ISIS has attacked Libya's oil fields to disrupt oil markets and prevent rival groups from profiting, but they assert that ISIS does not have the ability to control, refine, and sell the oil for millions of dollars a week. Experts argue that ISIS is primarily interested in starving the Libyan state of oil revenues. Therefore, the claim made by Trump is false.

CLAIM: Donald Trump claimed that he was "totally against the war in Iraq" and had been saying for many years that it would destabilize the Middle East.

EXPLANATION: The record shows that while Trump had some early reservations about the war, there is no evidence that he warned about regional destabilization before or after the war started. His opposition to the war evolved about a year after it began. Therefore, the claim that he was "totally against the war in Iraq" and had been warning about its destabilizing effects is false.

SEN. BERNIE SANDERS claimed on Meet the Press that in 2014, 80 percent of poor people did not vote. While the actual figure is slightly lower, with about 75 percent of people earning under $10,000 and about 69 percent of those earning under $30,000 not voting, Sanders is still correct in highlighting the low turnout among the poor as a significant issue. Factors such as registration barriers, voter ID laws, lack of time and resources, and a sense of inefficacy contribute to the lower voter turnout among the poor. Overall, Sanders' claim is rated mostly true.

CLAIM: Donald Trump claimed during a campaign rally in Harrisburg that Pennsylvania has lost 35% of its manufacturing jobs since 2001, and Harrisburg has lost 40% of its manufacturing jobs since 2001.

EXPLANATION: According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, Pennsylvania did lose nearly 300,000 manufacturing jobs since January 2001, which corresponds to a 34% decrease. However, the claim about Harrisburg losing 40% of its manufacturing jobs is incorrect. The Bureau of Labor Statistics shows that Harrisburg actually experienced a decrease of 30% in manufacturing jobs. Overall, the claim is mostly true for Pennsylvania but inaccurate for Harrisburg.

During the April 14th Democratic debate in New York, Hillary Clinton claimed that there had not been a single question about a woman's right to make her own decisions about reproductive health care in any of the previous nine debates. Fact-checking revealed that while there were no direct questions about abortion, Clinton and Bernie Sanders both brought up the topic themselves in multiple debates. Therefore, the claim was rated as true.

During the Brooklyn presidential debate, Hillary Clinton claimed that Republicans still want to privatize Social Security and turn over the Social Security trust fund to Wall Street. However, this claim is exaggerated. While some Republicans, like Ted Cruz, have proposed a form of privatization involving personal accounts funded by a fraction of payroll taxes, none of the remaining GOP candidates have suggested turning over the trust fund to Wall Street. Clinton's statement takes a longstanding Democratic exaggeration about GOP overhaul proposals and makes it even further off-base.

SEN. BERNIE SANDERS claimed to Meet the Press that Hillary Clinton supports a federal minimum wage of $12 an hour, while he supports a $15 minimum wage. Sanders is correct that Clinton's official position is to raise the federal minimum wage to $12, but she also supports the Fight for 15 campaign, which advocates for higher minimum wages in individual states and cities. Clinton has expressed support for raising the minimum wage to $15 in certain areas, such as Los Angeles and New York. Therefore, Sanders' claim is mostly true.

In the April 15th, 2016 Democratic debate in New York, Hillary Clinton claimed that Bernie Sanders has been a reliable supporter of the NRA. While it is true that Sanders has voted against certain gun control measures, such as the Brady Bill, he has also voted in favor of banning assault weapons, closing the gun show loophole, and expanding background checks. Sanders has received low marks from the NRA for the past 20 years and does not have full-throated support from the gun lobby. Therefore, Clinton's claim that Sanders has been a reliable supporter of the NRA is a stretch.

During the Democratic presidential debate in Brooklyn, Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders claimed that he remains one of the poorer members of the United States Senate. According to a study by Capitol Hill newspaper Roll Call, Sanders' net worth ranked in the bottom one-fifth of the 100-member chamber for the 2014 calendar year. However, it is important to note that the study is based on congressional financial disclosure forms, which provide only broad ranges of income and have certain exemptions. While the data is not precise, a credible calculation using these forms placed Sanders as having the 19th lowest net worth in the Senate. Therefore, the claim is rated as mostly true.

On May 29th, 2016, Senator Bernie Sanders claimed on Meet the Press that Hillary Clinton supports and continues to support fracking. Sanders argued that Clinton's position on fracking is at odds with voters, as New Yorkers ended the practice in the state in 2014. Sanders called for a nationwide ban on fracking, while Clinton supports it with conditions such as local choice, stronger environmental regulation, and disclosure of chemicals used. Sanders' claim is accurate, but it needs additional information.
